resources.string: Unable to capture or import photo
Unable to capture myPicture without the camera permission
Please confirm that you want to delete this myPicture.
Properties Not found, Click Floating button to add property.
Please confirm that you want to delete this Property unit.
The value is similar to purchased priced,If repairs/remodeling are not required.
Enter Federal tax rate for after tax cash flow calculations.
Lot Size \n (leave blank for house without lot area)
MLS Number \n(Leave blank if not understood)
The price of the Property.\n\n Does not include the purchase costs or costs to repair.
The estimated market value of the Property after repairs and updates.

The costs and fees associated with purchasing the property.\n\n Examples of purchasing costs include: appraisal, Sales and purchase argreement, loan agreement fees, and other processing fees for first year.
The costs for repairing and Remodel Property purchased.\n\nExamples include paint, flooring and cleaning.
The total values of all rents collected from tenants. Does not consider vacancy or expenses.

Any additional income besides than that from rents.\n\nThis may include other services provided to tenants, such as yard maintenance, house cleaning, utilities, and coin-operated laundry and vending machine proceeds.
All the expenses paid while renting a property.\n\nExamples include insurance, 3rd party warranties, maintenance, property taxes, and utilities.

The percentage of time the property is expected not being rented.

Ideally the property will and must always be rented. However, the property sometimes may be vacant between tenants or during repairing/ remodeling .

Example: if the property is expected to be vacant one month out of the year, this is 1/12=8.3% (for using days formula = 30/365)
The yearly increase of the Property\'s value.\n\nThis can be due to a number of reasons, which include increased demand or reduced supply, or inflation.
The yearly increase of the income generated by the property.\n\nInflation is the typical cause of the increase. This affects both the rent and other income from the property.
The yearly increase of the expenses paid while renting the prperty.\n\nInflation is the typical cause of the increase, and affects all expenses.
The costs and fees associated with selling the Property. This is also called closing costs.\n\nExamples include real estate agent commissions, taxes, home warranty, and escrow fees.
The value of the land alone, i.e. the value of the Property less the value of the dwelling and other structures.\n\nThis is used in calculating the depreciation deduction of the Property.
The total amount of cash needed to purchase the property, repair, and update it.
$$\\text{Total Cash Needed} = \\text{Down Payment} + \\text{Purchase Costs} + \\text{Repair and Update Costs}$$
All the income generated by renting Property plus Other income minus vacancies.

All the income generated by renting a property, minus Operating Expenses.\n\nThis does not take into account loan payments. Because of this, Net Operating Income can be used to compare properties independent of financing.
The amount of money received from a rental property as income.\n\nThis accounts for all income sources and all expenses, including loan payments.

A rate of return on a rental property that compares the yearly Net Operating Income and the Purchase Price.\n\nThis does not take into account loan payments. Because of this, the Capitalization Rate can be used to compare properties independent of financing.
A rate of return on a rental property that compares the yearly Cash Flow and Total Invested Cash.\n\nThis represents the yearly return on the invested cash.
$$\\text{Cash On Cash} = \\frac{\\text{Yearly Cash Flow}}{\\text{Total Invested Cash}}$$
A rate of return on a rental a Property that compares the yearly Gross Rent and the Property\'s Market Value.

A rate of return on a rental Property that compares the Purchase Price and the yearly Gross Rent.\n\nIt represents the number of years it will take for the yearly Gross Rent to add to the purchase price.

The current value of the property.\n\nThis may not be the same as the purchase price, as the property may have been purchased at a discount, repairs or updated may have been made, the property has appreciated over time, etc.

The portion of the property\'s market value that you own. If using a loan, this depends on the balance of the loan. Equity will increase as the loan is paid down and the property\'s value appreciates.

Instead of deducting the cost of purchasing a Property all in one year, many country\'s require that the cost of a rental be taken over the property\'s useful lifespan.\n\nIn the US, the useful lifespan of a property is considered 27.5 years. If ot in the US, check the local tax laws on rental property depreciation rules.
The portion of the mortgage payment which is the interest portion of the loan.\n\nIn some countries one can deduct the mortgage interest from one\'s taxes. Check local tax laws for more information.
Add any purchase costs or closing costs, which may include legal fees, property inspection fees,Bank processing fee, and Loan Facility Agreement\â€™s. Note: the names must be unique.
Add any repair costs, which may include paint, flooring, appliances, cleaning, and updates. Note: naming must be unique.
Add any expenses per month, which may include housing tax, insurance, 3rd party warranties, and etc. Note: naming must be unique.
Analyze rental properties to determine the best investment!\n\n
Add a new property by touching the plus from the property list.\n\nEnter a nickname, address, and any other information you want.
Touch Worksheet to enter details, including purchase price, financing, repair/remodel costs, monthly rent, and other information.
After filling out the worksheet, touch Summary to see details on the deal, including cash needed, first year\'s operation, and returns. \n\nTouch Projections to see future operations and returns.
Images of the property can be captured on the Pictures page, and notes can be recorded on the Notes page.
